awd_titl_txt: CSBR: Natural History: Improvement of the Mississippi Entomological Museum for organization of collection and digitization of specimen data
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mississippi Entomological Museum at Mississippi State University holds more than 1.6 million research specimens from all 50 states of the U.S. and 48 other countries.  This research resource is especially important in documenting the insect diversity of the southern Coastal Plain, including many imperiled habitats.  The collection also holds specimens of disease vectors as well as agricultural and forestry pests that have been documented in Mississippi for the past 120 years, and these specimens are important for evaluating their past, current, and future distributions.  The museum's identification center provides early detection of invasive species that threaten the biosecurity of food, fiber, and forests in 13 states.  The acquisition of specimens from these activities has resulted in unique holdings among biological collections in the U.S., and these include major collections of ants and grasshoppers.  More than 100 species new to science have been described based on specimens held in the collection with many more still to be described.  During the past five years, the museum has hosted 112 visiting researchers from 42 institutions in 25 states and five other countries.  Concurrently, the museum has an active education and outreach program with curricula designed for elementary students and table events involving displays and informative hand-outs provided at public events.  The annual growth of collection holdings during the past five years has approached 30% because of fieldwork, donations, trap samples from other states, and acquisition of other institutional collections.  At present the museum is over full capacity, with cabinets holding specimens limiting access in hallways and offices, and no space is available for future additions of specimens.

This project has three objectives.  The first is to expand storage space for research specimens by acquisition of a compactor system that will include moveable carriages on rails that hold cabinets.  This compactor system will provide an estimated 30% increase in capacity.  The second objective is to resolve the current hazards of storage of flammable preservatives in a multi-use building that includes classrooms for students.  Almost 400,000 curated specimens and a large number of bulk samples are currently stored in ethanol and held in various rooms and hallways (some adjacent to classrooms) of the Clay Lyle Entomology Building.  This concentration of specimens in alcohol has presented a safety hazard because the volatility of the preservative.  The acquisition of a walk-in refrigerated unit, located outside the building, would alleviate the current hazards of storing specimens in ethanol in the building.  The third objective will be the digitization of specimen label data for ants and grasshoppers.  Both ants and grasshoppers have ecological and economic significance to the public, especially for invasive species of ants.  The museum has the third largest collections of both groups of insects in eastern U.S., but specimen data are currently unavailable to others.  The digitization effort will make these data available to researchers and the public through data sharing with iDigBio (iDigBio.org) and other global resources such as the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Mississippi Entomological Museum (MEM) is one of the largest university collections in southeastern U.S. with the number of prepared specimens exceeding 1,700,000 and with more than 35,000 specimens being added annually. While holdings in the collection are primarily from the Southeast, the museum holds specimens from all 50 states of the U.S. as well as 48 other countries.

The MEM is located near the center of the North American Coastal Plain, which was recognized in 2016 by Conservation International as the world?s 36th biodiversity hotspot. IThe MEM has the richest holdings from throughout the Coastal Plain of any other collection in the Southeast. This valuable material has been studied by museum staff and loaned to other researchers resulting in descriptions of endemic new species and disjunct distribution patterns in a wide range of taxa.  

There were four goals of this funded project: 1)  purchase and install a compactor system to house the collection of pinned specimens; 2), purchase 10 cabinets (each 48 drawer capacity) to replace 16 unsecure wood cabinets; 3) purchase and install a walk-in freezer (8'x14') to store specimens stored in ethanol; 4) digitize data for 16,336 specimens of grasshoppers and 87,221 specimens of ants.

Outcomes

  Goal 1: A compactor system with eight carriages (each holding 10, 48-drawer cabinets) was purchased from FSM (Filing and Storage of Mississippi) and installed during Dec. 12, 2018 - January 7, 2019. 

Goal 2: Ten new cabinets were obtained to house material in wooden cabinets.  Re-organization of the collection has been completed, and directories of cabinet contents have been made. 

Goal 3: A blast-proof, American Walk-in Cooler (8? x 14? x 8?h) was  installed on a concrete pad and fitted with metal racks  (Figs. 1).  Movement of bulk samples and other unidentified material in alcohol to the cooler was in December 2020.

 Goal 4: Formicidae:  We proposed to enter 87,221 ant specimens into the Symbiota Collections of Arthropods Network (SCAN) Data Portal at:  https://scan-bugs.org/portal/. during this project. However, we were able to enter 106,386 individual ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), surpassing our goal by 19,165  specimens.  Of the 106,386 specimens now digitized, 98% are identified to species and 90% are georeferenced.   These include 514 species in 93 genera from 43 countries and all 50 states of the United States. (Fig. 2). This data has been made available to iDigBio and GBIF portals.

Acrididae:  We proposed to enter 16,336 grasshopper specimens into the Symbiota Collections of Arthropods Network (SCAN) Data Portal at:  https://scan-bugs.org/portal/. during this project. However, we were able to enter 17,800 individual grasshoppers (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), surpassing our goal by 1,464 specimens.  Of the total number of digitized specimens, 96% have been identified and include 489 species and subspecies in 209 genera. Specimens have been digitized from 31 countries and all 50 states of the United States, with most specimens being represented from the southeastern United States. (Fig.3.)

Outreach: Outreach and education programs related to this project have been provided through two avenues: 1) visits by groups to the museum, and 2) the Bug Blues program that involves museum staff providing educational programs to schools and public events. 

During the period of July 1, 2018 to December 31, 2021, tours and presentations were given to an estimated 2011 people, mostly in school groups. In July 2018, Spring 2019, and Fall 2019 prior to COVID-19 shutdowns, an average of 544 people toured the museum each semester. With most planned school group field trips, stations were established for smaller group activities. One of the stations involved a 20-minute tour of the museum that included seeing the curated specimens as well as display drawers of exotic species.

From March 2020 until May 2021, no in-person tours took place in the museum or zoo to maintain safety recommendations for indoor gatherings. In Spring 2021, a virtual museum tour was created and uploaded to YouTube as part of a bigger series. The museum tour video garnered 47 views, though this is probably not an accurate count of viewership as the videos were advertised mainly to schools. According to relevant health guidelines, in-person tours resumed cautiously in late spring of 2021. From Spring 2021 to Fall 2021, about 65 people toured the museum per semester.   

In addition to museum tours and educational opportunities on campus, Bug Blues also traveled to dozens of events around the state and a handful outside of Mississippi. Different museums? events allowed Bug Blues to present unique material, often including pinned display drawers and discussion of the museum?s work and the importance of natural history collections, reaching more than 12,200 people from 2018-2021.
